subject: Re: [junit] Re: if setUp fails, then is setUp doing too much?
msgSnippet: Do I understand correctly? You appear to be using the TestCase object to create test cases that will be executed by something else. This is not what JUnit was
messageBody:
Do I understand correctly?

You appear to be using the TestCase object to create test cases that
will be executed by something else. This is not what JUnit was designed
for, so I am confused why you are doing things this way.

Why are you writing XML tags at all?

Reading more, you appear to be doing logging in the test case. Why are
you not doing this logging in something like a test runner?

Thanks.

So said martijn_dashorst <yahoogroups@...> on 2/13/2003
--------------------

>J.B. Rainsberger wrote:
>> if setUp fails, then is setUp doing too much?
>
>I agree that it gives a bad smell, but let me expand a bit.
>
>In short: if you use the setUp()/tearDown() to write XML start/close
>tags, then it is very cumbersome that tearDown() isn't called. This
>will break your continuous integration cycle.
>
>The long version:
>
>I created a TestCase subclass so that we could write more readable
>functional tests. It is for an Interactive Voice Response system. The
>functional tests assert that the correct voice segments are played in
>the in the right order at the right time.
>
>In my subclass, a XML start tag is written in the setUp(), and it's
>closing tag in the tearDown(). Note that the functional tests should
>be read and written by business people, that's why I finalized setUp
>and tearDown. Example code:
>
>public abstract class CallFlowTestCase extends TestCase{
> final void setUp() {
> phone.hangUp();
> log.write( "<test name=\"" + getName() + "\">" );
> beforeTest();
> }
> final void tearDown(){
> afterTest();
> log.write( "</test>" );
> phone.hangUp();
> }
> public void beforeTest(){
> }
> public void afterTest(){
> }
> // etc.
>}
>
>public class TestHelloWorldLine extends CallFlowTestCase {
> public void beforeTest(){
> dial( "12345678" );
> assertPhoneStatus( CONNECTED );
> }
> public void testHelloWorld(){
> assertVoiceSegment( "HELLOWORLD.wav" );
> }
>}
>
>Shared callflow navigation, setting opening hours, or other
>parameters should typically be done in the setUp() method. This
>avoids much duplication of testcode and it is its purpose.
>
>Of course this can be done with methods, but that also leeds to
>duplication of code, noticable in large test classes (connect
>();navigateMenu1();navigateMenu2();navigateMenu3(); in each test
>method for class TestMenu4 clouds the test scenario to my taste).
>
>The client code in beforeTest() can fail, for example:
> * The application at number 12345678 might not be running),
> * some default navigation (always dial 1 at the start)
> doesn't give the expected result due to a different
> parameter setting the testwriter didn't account for.
>It is very inconvenient if the closing tag isn't written after each
>test. The application logs several messages (which voice segments
>were written, etc) to this log between the opening/end tags. This
>helps debugging the IVR application (or, quite often, the test).
>
>Martijn Dashorst
